column2: Three state agencies are fighting for garbage. New York City wants them to have it for conversion into energy--but the city also wants to make sure that the price will be right.

In a move to reduce sharply New York's dependence on oil, the state's Energy Office called yesterday for an increase in the use of coal and natural gas over the next 15 years but opposed any new nuclear-power plants beyond two that are already near completion.
Dr. Michael M. Baden said yesterday he would file a lawsuit against the Koch administration seeking reinstatement as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner.

BOSTON--Each round of "updated," "revised" college-level American history textbooks delivers more of the same irrelevant political history. In their race to capture the classroom market, publishers distort our political past and render it superficial.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)--Richard A. Viguerie, who has run many successful fund-raising efforts for various conservative causes and candidates, has joined the campaign of John B. Connally, a Republican Presidential hopeful, as a volunteer, it was announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 7--The British are seething at what they consider unwarranted American interference in the delicate problem of Northern Ireland, this time because of remarks made yesterday by Governor Carey of New York.
W. Robert LaVine, a theatrical costume designer, died following heart surgery Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--President Carter's proposal to invest $88 billion in synthetic fuel development encountered renewed opposition today in significant Congressional quarters.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 7--President Carter boarded the 8 o'clock Metroliner at Washington's Union Station this morning and journeyed here in a snack-bar coach to rally support for his energy program and praise the contributions of ethnic Americans.
The pound, affected by concern over inflation in Britain, continued to slide on world money markets yesterday, but the dollar held steady against other currencies as gold prices advanced.

The Federal Government has warned School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola that before any new teachers are hired this fall, all current teacher examinations must be analyzed to determine if they discriminate against candidates on the basis of race or sex.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7--The executive council of the A.F.L-C.I.O. today announced its support of the treaty with the Soviet Union to limit strategic nuclear arms.

The normally turbulent Chicago markets in grain and soybean futures became extremely cautious late yesterday as the trade awaited the crop estimates of Conrad Leslie, the leading private forecaster in the industry.
Michele Sindona, an Italian financier charged with a multimillion-dollar fraud involving the Franklin National Bank, remained officially listed yesterday as a "missing person."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--On his way back here from Iowa a couple of days ago, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, one of nine announced or unannounced Republican Presidential candidates, was asked what he was going to do at a National Press Club speech this week that would be different.

As part of a new effort to halt the illegal conversion of industrial loft buildings to residential spaces, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city had gone to court to block the owners of a building in lower Manhattan from converting it. The city is also requesting that the owners be required to restore the building to industrial use.
TOKYO, Aug. 7--(Reuters) The Japanese Cabinet today ruled out an imminent oil-supply crisis here, because of increased Saudi Arabian production and a calmer spot market, a Government spokesman said.

The State of California's $125 million issue of general obligation bonds--this week's big event in the tax-exempt sector--came to market yesterday with a group headed by the Bankers Trust Company as the winning bidder.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP)--Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe, announced today that its broadcast subsidiary had agreed in principle to buy two Springfield, Mass., radio stations for $5.1 million.

At the invitation of Mexican authorities, the Rainbow Art Foundation of New York has commissioned 12 artists to prepare works for an exhibition, "The Icarus Odyssey," to be mounted in Guadalajara in October.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Secretary of Defense Harold Brown has approved a detailed plan for basing the Air Force's new MX mobile missile, Pentagon officials said today.

BUCHANAN, N.Y. Aug. 7--More than half of the 106 antinuclear protesters arraigned in Village Court here today on charges of trespassing at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point power plant refused to give their names and were returned to the Westchester County Jail pending a hearing on Monday.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 7-- Americans finished first and second today in the fourth race in the Admiral's Cup, a biennial gathering of the world's best ocean racing yachts.
EAST BERLIN--East Germany, troubled for some time by energy problems and supply shortages, has failed to meet production targets in the first half of this year in several vital fields.
PEKING, Aug. 7 (UPI)--China should be granted most-favored-nation status in trade with the United States, regardless of whether the Soviet Union qualifies for it, Senator Henry M. Jackson said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The Carter Administration said today that Israel might have violated an agreement with the United States by using American-supplied planes against Lebanon last month. At the same time, officials tried to reassure Israel that the United States had not changed its policy toward the Palestine Liberation Organization and that anxiety over oil supplies was not causing pressure to be brought against Israel.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 7 (AP)-- Armed Islamic revolutionary guards occupied the offices of a leading Teheran newspaper today, and a Government official said its publishers and editors would be prosecuted for "counterrevolutionary policies and acts."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)--Minute amounts of cancer-causing agents called nitrosamines have been found in six brands of Scotch whisky, the National Science Foundation reported today.

Lou Brock moved within eight hits of his goal of 3,000 last night in Shea Stadium but the New York Mets moved only closer to oblivion as the St. Louis Cardinals swept a doubleheader behind some extravagant rookie pitching.

Has some advertisement lied to you lately? Thanks to the vigilance of the Federal Trade Commission, claims that this pill will grow hair or that that compound will double gas mileage have become rare. Thus it's ironic that the Commission's staff, in its zeal to protect gullible consumers, may be making it impossible for honest retailers to compete by advertising lower prices.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 7--After three days of meetings with Nicaraguan leaders, Senator Edward Zorinsky, the chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, said today that the United States must not "abdicate its responsibilities" in aiding the new Government.

MENLO PARK, Calif., Aug. 7--Although seismologists have been able to predict some recent earthquakes, yesterday's temblor in northern California came without warning, scientists at the United States Geological Survey said today.

It brought a total of just under $5 million, which even in these inflationary times is no mean sum, and yet I heard few exclamations of surprise when the final tally was announced.

Like other communities, Plainfield, N.J., has used zoning to insulate itself from communes and other experimental life styles. No more than four unrelated people could live together in a single-family dwelling unit. Now the New Jersey Supreme Court has struck down the limit saying it does not accurately reflect the way people live today.

WASHINGTON A HUNDRED MILES above central Asia, an American satellite suddenly switches into operation. Although it is the dead of night, the spacecraft's camera takes hundreds of photograph's of a suspicious construction site near a Soviet intercontinental ballistic missile complex. Minutes later, as the satellite passes over Australia, the infrared photos are transmitted to an American-operated ground station and then relayed to the Central Intelligence Agency in Langley, Va.

Gold futures rose to records for the third consecutive day yesterday but closed lower after traders took profits, while signs that the Federal Reserve has tightened credit depressed interest rate futures.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 24 (AP)-- Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he would stay away from the constitutional conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia in London next month if his presence proved to be a stumbling block to a settlement.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 24 (AP)--A former adviser to Howard R. Hughes was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for obstruction of justice.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Rev. Bernard T. Pagano, cleared of charges that he was the "Gentleman Bandit" who held up six northern Delaware stores at gunpoint, could still face trial in Pennsylvania on a charge of attempted robbery, the authorities said today.

Collin Ross, Johnny Handle and Tom Gilfellon play the fiddle, pipes, bones, tin whistle and guitar, and join in on the traditional songs.

People magazine announced yesterday that from now on it would peg its ad rates to the magazine's circulation on an issue-by-issue basis, rather than to the average circulation over a six-month period, the traditional method in the magazine business. Last Saturday in Williamsport, Pa., they jogged onto the field in close formation, boot-camp style, and when they jogged off they had the seventh Little League world championship in nine years under their belts.

Bobby Cox was one happy manager yesterday after watching his last-place Atlanta Braves complete a three-game sweep of the last-place New York Mets at Shea Stadium. The 5-4 victory had the one-time Yankee third baseman thinking along ambitious lines.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29 (AP) With an unofficial cease-fire reported holding in the Kurdish center of Mehabad, the state radio said today that an agreement had been reached for the Iranian Army to enter the rebel-held northwestern city to take over security.

The continuing rise in the prime interest rate, which now stands at a record 12 percent at most banks, is putting a squeeze on companies that finance large inventories of unsold goods with borrowed funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) None of the four pipeline plans proposed for carrying Alaskan oil to the energy-hungry Middle West offer significant advantages environmentally, the Interior Department said in an environmental impact statement.

Black, Hispanic and women's rights leaders urged Mayor Koch yesterday to set up "community hiring halls" that would be similar to labor-union hiring halls. The goal would be to insure that members of minority groups were hired at city construction sites where public funds were involved.

Approximately 125 samples of glass representing a wide variety of periods and styles went on view this week in the new Decorative Arts Gallery of the museum. The show will continue through Nov. 25.

In a move designed to reduce harassment of officials, the National Basketball Association's board of governors voted yesterday to limit the movement of coaches and trainers during games.

The future of Off Off Broadway is in doubt because of the new Actors Equity showcase code scheduled to go into effect on Saturday. Reginald Lanier, a former New York investment banker, died yesterday at Newport Hospital in Newport, R.I., after a long illness. The 90-year-old financier lived in Newport and Manhattan.

Samuel I. Newhouse, the restless, selfmade newspaper magnate who ran his 31 newspapers out of a battered briefcase, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital of the effects of a stroke. Mr. Newhouse, who was known in the business world as S.I., was 84 years old.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29, (Reuters) The Seagram Company, the world's largest producer and marketer of alcoholic beverages, said today that it would record a gain of more than $75 million due to new British tax legislation.

Determined to win delegates and influence Republicans in this state, Ronald Reagan yesterday took the unusual step of intervening in a local political fight. He endorsed the Suffolk County Executive, John V.N. Klein, for renomination in both the Republican and Conservative primaries Sept. 11.

The dollar was mixed on foreign currency exchanges at home and abroad Wednesday in trading described by one dealer as "uneventful." The price of gold retreated slightly from its record high of Tuesday, but set a new closing record in London.

KANSAS began its Tuesday evening concert at Madison Square Garden with a string of direct, uptempo rockers and a healthy dose of the sort of energy and momentum that Middle Western hard-rock bands have long been noted for.

Prices of most debt issues closed a touch lower yesterday as most retail business continued slow. Dealers said much of the trading was among themselves as they prepared for the long holiday weekend.

Aleksandr Godunov, the former Bolshoi ballet star, said at a news conference yesterday that he had acted "solely for artistic reasons" when he defected to the United States a week ago. He also said that he believed his wife would not have chosen to return home if he had been able to talk with her.

J.P. Stevens Company, the textiles manufacturer involved in a long and labor, reported yesterday that it had its highest quarterly earnings in five years. Stevens said its profits surged 36.6 percent for the three months ended Aug. 4 and 28.4 percent for the ninemonths period.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has deplored "Monty Python's Life of Brian," a film satire by the British comedy group Monty Python, as "a mockery of Christ's life."

TRENTON, Aug. 29 New Jersey health officials announced today a new system of uniform statewide hospital rates. It would reward institutions where charges are lower than average and would force economies on less efficient hospitals.

Still quivering from the Ilie NastaseJohn McEnroe fireworks of the night before, the United States Open tennis championships settled down yesterday with a more ordinary run of upsets, marathon struggles, nervous tension and children playing patty-ball under the stadium lights of the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5 --The Giants stood pat today. All was quiet on their offensive front. They did not claim anyone on waivers, did not sign any free agents, did not lure anyone out of retirement.

Because of the Labor Day holiday, the statistics prepared by the American Petroleum Institute to describe the previous week's oil imports, output at the nation's refineries and inventories of crude oil and refined products will be delayed this week, a spokesman said yesterday. Preliminary statistics for any given week are normally available the following Wednesday afternoon. Last week's preliminary figures will instead be available this afternoon, he said.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 (AP)-- Resorts International Inc. announced today that it had a monthly gross win of $23.8 million for August at its Boardwalk casino.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP)--The 320strong production force at Boston Whaler's two boat-building plants in Norwell and Rockland, Mass., struck yesterday shutting down the assembly line at the motorboat plant.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Applications for 1,700 low-interest mortgages were snapped up today by wouldbe home buyers, about 3,000 of whom had waited up to six days outside 61 loan offices with sleeping bags, beach chairs and umbrellas.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 5 (Reuters)--Iranian oil production has dropped almost 20 percent from average levels of around 3.75 million barrels a day last month, according to figures issued by the National Iranian Oil Company.

Before choosing a candidate for Bronx Borough President next Tuesday, voters might ask themselves why there are four names on the Democratic ballot. Who wants to assume a role bristling with so many difficulties and blessed with so few powers? The hypothetical answers to that question may help the voter choose.

Guy Bolton, the author or co-author of dozens of light, romantic Broadway musicals that won wide audiences in the 1920's and 30's, died Tuesday in Goringon-Thames, which is near London. He was 96 years old.

Sea-Land Service, a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, said yesterday that it had resumed containerized freight operations in the port of Rio Haina, Dominican Republic, following Hurricane David.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--The United States intelligence community has been receiving reports indicating the presence of Soviet combat units in Cuba for at least eight years, high-ranking Administration officials said today. But only in recent weeks did intelligence officials tentatively conclude that the troops were an organized combat force.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 2--The Soviet Union has been unable to find a political solution to the fighting here and, according to diplomatic sources, there are signs that Moscow is moving toward direct, broad military intervention to quell the dozens of fierce local uprisings.

LONDON, Sept. 5--Not many of the major figures of World War II are left now that Earl Mountbatten of Burma is gone, Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia, Gen. Omar N. Bradley. And Averell Harriman, who led the official American delegation to the ceremonial funeral of his friend of 50 years.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5-- Much of Northern Ireland fell silent today in tribute to Earl Mountbatten of Burma and the 1,957 other men, women and children who have died in the past decade of Irish violence.

IN New York City, where life--or at least urban design--so often borders on the uncivilized, there is one amenity that is consistently gracious, almost always useful and frequently attractive. It is the canopy, the protective extension of metal or glass or canvas or vinyl that keeps away rain and snow along the path from front door to taxi, and acts as a symbolic welcoming device as well.
Archibald Stevens Alexander, Under Secretary of the Army in the Truman Administration, died Tuesday at his home in Bernardsville, N.J., after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

The new television season began last night for Johnny Carson, who returned to his familiar desk on NBC-TV's "Tonight" show after a summer vacation. But it is still uncertain whether the popular comedian will be at that post when the season ends, or even after Sept. 30, the date that will mark his 17th anniversary as host of the nightly talkand-variety program.

The card featuring the Larry Holmes-Earnie Shavers fight for the World Boxing Council's heavyweight title was rounded out yesterday with bouts including Roberto Duran and Sugar Ray Leonard. The card is scheduled for Sept. 28 in Las Vegas, Nev.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 5--She is a thin reed of a woman with a small pile of coconuts and avocados at her feet, picked from the ground and brought to the capital for sale in a desperate search for money to keep her family going.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI)-- Australia, New Zealand and four Central American nations may increase exports of meat to the United States to make up a 56-million-pound shortfall in Mexican shipments, the Agriculture Department said today.

THE Grateful Dead, for some reason or other, has become the New York area's biggest cult rock band, as attested to-- in this time of supposed music-industry recession--by its arrival Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden for the first of three sold-out concerts.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 (Reuters)--Sofu Teshigahara, the 78-year-old sculptor and founder of the Sogetsu flower-arranging school, died at a Tokyo hospital today, the hospital said. Mr. Teshigahara received many international awards, including France's Legion of Honor in 1961. He published books on flower arranging in several languages.

Silver futures rose as much as 73 cents an ounce yesterday, soaring to a new all-time high for the ninth successive trading session. At the close, prices were one-third higher than a month ago.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 5 (AP)--A bomb exploded near a Jerusalem swimming pool today, slightly injuring a man, the police reported. Earlier in the day, several Israelis were injured when a bottle of chlorine exploded at the Tel Aviv bus station, but the police said that the explosion had been an accident.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (UPI)--Omar Moreno and Dave Parker both scored on a wild pickoff attempt by Darold Knowles in the 11th inning tonight leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The victory kept the first-place Pirates two games ahead of Montreal in the National League East race.

But then I read the opening paragraph of David Axelrod's confession:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)--Ten protesters against nuclear arms were arrested today at the Pentagon after they threw red paint on the building and blocked an entrance, the police said. Seven were charged with destruction of Government property, the others with failing to obey a police officer's directions. They were taking part in a six-hour demonstration by 35 members of the Atlantic Life Community, based in Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)-- The average price of gold sold today at the International Monetary Fund's monthly auction was a $333.24 an ounce.

Antinuclear activists will stage a rally on Sept. 23 at the Battery Park City landfill, south of the World Trade Center. The rally has been planned in conjunction with the series of antinuclear/pro-solar benefit rock concerts earlier that week at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today defended conversations that Israel's Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, has had with Palestinian Arabs who support the Palestine Liberation Organization.

HAVANA, Sept. 5--President Fidel Castro of Cuba met growing resistance from third world governments today to his efforts to bring their movement closer to the Soviet position on world issues and to control their conference here.

ON Tuesday evening, ABC-TV ofred a "preview" of a new weekly series called "The Lazarus Syndrome." Its hero is a doctor and the principal setting is a hospital. WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)--The Senate voted today to urge former President Richard M. Nixon to repay the Government for improvements made at taxpayer expense that increased the value of his estate in San Clemente, Calif.

The Metropolitan Museum is marking the 25th anniversary of concerts in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium with the presentation of 65 musical events during the 1979-80 season. Since the first program played in 1954 by Isaac Stern, 1,312 concerts have been given in the auditorium, most of them devoted to chamber music.

While Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert Lloyd, the defending champions, and Billie Jean King, the "old lady" gathering a youthful second wind, reached the semifinals of the United States Open yesterday, the real commotion at the National Tennis Center was the combination of events--some planned, others spontaneous--that produced a scheduling mixup in the second week of the tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO--There is a line of thought these days that the courts, like other American institutions, need exposing. The mystique of the robe should be stripped away, it is said. The inner workings of appellate courts, the judges' motives, their exchanges in the privacy of the conference room: All should be known to the public in a democracy.
LADDERS are probably among the most commonly used "tools" around most homes, especially at this time of year when there is more than an average amount of fixing and sprucing up going on.

Opponents of a plan to build a 58-story skyscraper to replace the abandoned Bonwit Teller building on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street urged the City Planning Commission yesterday to deny zoning changes requested by the developer.

Tropical Storm David--downgraded from a hurricane, but still laden with water and spinning off tornados as it moved--lumbered toward the New York City area this morning, threatening to dump an estimated three to five inches of rain and cause some beach damage before blowing away by tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 5-- Andrew Young left today on his final diplomatic assignment as a Government official, heading a White House trade mission to Africa.

The planned acquisition of the Microwave Semiconductor Corporation by Siemens A.G. has been postponed. The merger, which was to take place on Sept. 30, has been delayed until about Nov. 15, according to an announcement by the companies.
A monthlong revival of "The Sound of Music" will begin the 37th season of the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. The production will open on Sept. 20 and run through Oct. 14.

LIZA MINNELLI came into Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening trailing an impressive collection of awards behind her-- three Tonys, an Oscar and an Emmy. But when she leaves Carnegie Hall a week from tomorrow after a run of 11 nights, she will be taking with her something far more important than awards.
Philip C. Lewis, an author and dramatist, died Monday of leukemia in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (UPI)--The Chrysler Corporation's $400 customer rebate program helped push its lateAugust car sales 23 percent above the level of the corresponding period last year--a far better performance than that of the other Big Three auto makers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today that mutual funds be permitted to use their assets for marketing purposes.

Despite the presence of two police detectives from a newly formed bank-robbery squad, a man passed a note to a teller, showed her a gun and fled by taxi with $784 from the European American Bank at Park Avenue and 40th Street yesterday. The detectives learned of the robbery too late to signal other members of the stakeout team waiting outside.
KUWAIT, Sept. 5 (UPI)--Libya has replaced Syrian jets that the Israelis shot down with more advanced models, the newspaper Al Rai al Am reported today.

Two firemen were injured yesterday as they fought a two-alarm fire of unknown origin at a three-story apartment building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Residents of the dwelling, at 560 Fourth Avenue, escaped without injury. The injured men were identified as Frederick Meyers, who suffered from heat exhaustion, and Robert McNellis, who sustained neck burns. Officials said both were treated and released from Methodist Hospital.

RUTHERFORD, N.J. Sept. 5--Fall classes were to open at Fairleigh Dickinson University today for Jerry Deveney and friends. But the faculty struck in midmorning after fruitless, all-night contract talks, and Mr. Deveney and a dozen or so classmates wound up sitting on a bench outside Becton Hall, sharing some before-noon beers and a bottle of wine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--The primary purpose of the 3,000-man Soviet armored brigade in Cuba is to protect a massive new "communications intercept facility," which will give the Russians the ability to listen in on most United States telephone conversations as well as to monitor transmission of data between computers and from our satellites and missiles.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5--The Presidential campaign of Ronald Reagan, the acknowledged front-runner for the 1980 Republican nomination, is at least $500,000 in debt and is raising money at a substantially lower pace than the staff anticipated, according to sources in the Reagan organization.

LOS ANGELES--This is the international year of the child, and the "children" have taken over Nicaragua. The average age in Latin America is 14. Nicaragua is no exception. Veteran Sandinists with three years of combat under their belt informed me when I was in Nicaragua that they are now 16 years of age. But these heroic youngsters lack the technical skills to administer an economy. Who is going to do it?

TEL AVIV, Sept. 5--The Voice of Israel broadcast recipes for bread today and advised housewives to bake their own to cope with a shortage caused by a protest action of bakery workers demanding a 30 percent wage increase.

MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 5 (AP)--Manchester City set a British soccer transfer record today, paying nearly $3 million for Steve Daley, 26year-old Wolverhampton midfielder.

The Fluor Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings increased 13 percent for the third fiscal quarter ending July 31 and 33 percent for the nine months. Retail sales in New York City last month showed the largest monthly gain in the last three and a half years, averaging 17.6 percent above the August 1978 level, a monthly spot check of six major city retail companies found yesterday.

SPIRAL staircases are an attractive way to gain access to another level without using a great deal of space, and many people find the sculptural forms are intriguing in their homes. Now there is a new twist in spirals: ready-to-install styles are available on the market.

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines announced yesterday the reassignment of its longtime general manager in New York, Frederick O. Kielman, whose office is the focus of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into allegations of secret loans and other financial misdealings by the airline.

PARIS, Sept. 5 (AP)--France raised taxes on income, pleasure boats, private planes, cars, cigarettes and liquor today, and said it also planned to tax oil-company profits. Treasury officials said they were trying to avert a recession that could result from oil-price increases.

He has represented West Germany in many trade talks since 1965, including those with the Soviet Union and China.

The 230-foot Mary's Ketch, registered in Britain and with a home port of Grand Cayman Island, was being towed to Tampa today.

Following an idea tried in Washington, the Nassau-Suffolk Bridge Association will honor a longtime director this weekend. At Adeiphi University, Garden City, L.I., Harry Goldwater will be a player instead of the director, his customary role for more than 30 years.

In Boston somebody said Carl Yastrzemski had made his first hit when John F. Kennedy was President and might not make his 3,000th until Teddy was. However, after a delay that was beginning to make everyone's teeth hurt, Yaz did the deed in time to be congratulated by President Carter.

The United States, for all of its political and economic problems, has drawn the highest credit rating of 93 countries measured on a scale of zero to 10 by 50 international banks. It received an overall score of 9.89. West Germany was rated second at 9.83. The next three countries were Switzerland, 9.82; Japan, 9.69, and Canada, 9.35.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 Reginald Peters works in a noisy place that is often hot and has the odor, the feeling, of grease and machines an automobile plant. Automobile bodies, hauled by a chain device on the floor, pass him once every 1.15 minutes, 52 every hour, 416 every day. Mr. Peters is that mythic Detroit man, the American legend, the assembly line worker.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. On Cape Cod last month and in the Berkshires, Senator Edward M. Kennedy romped and relaxed with his family, in what may be the last private moments that he will enjoy for many years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has "expanded" its investigation of alleged cocaine use by Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, after receiving new accusations that Mr. Jordan used cocaine at a party in Los Angeles in October 1977, according to Justice Department officials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) Israel's Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, arrived here today in search of aid, arms and the right to build one of the most advanced United States warplanes.
Silver futures recovered to resume a five-week rally yesterday, while gold futures set new highs on renewed speculative buying.

Asa S. Herzog, a 75-year-old former bankruptcy judge in Manhattan Federal court, will join Gelberg Kronovet of New York, a new commercial law firm, effective Oct. 1, Frederick Gelberg, senior partner, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has linked his Presidential intentions to the condition of the economy, said today that he did not differ substantially with President Carter's economic policies but suggested that stronger leadership was necessary to make them work.
TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP) A 46-member Japanese business mission will leave for the United States next month to explore investment opportunities.

Lee Goerner, a 32-year-old assistant editor at Alfred A. Knopf, is this year's winner of the Tony Godwin Memorial Award. It is presented to an outstanding young editor from Britain or the United States and includes a stipend to work in a publishing house on either side of the Atlantic Ocean for six weeks. He plans to work for the British paperback house Pan Books next spring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP) Ann McGuire, 25 years old, survived a leap from the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday and was listed in "serious condition" today after extensive surgery. She was was believed to be the 11th person to survive the 211-foot plunge. She was found in the moat that encloses the base of the bridge's south tower, the authorities said.

As an attendant cleaned up refuse from the sidewalk, diners at an outdoor cafe on 52d Street and Third Avenue yesterday enjoyed mild summer temperatures and clear and sunny skies. Kenny Rogers will be host of the 13th telecast of the Country Music Awards Show, on Oct. 8. The broadcast, from 9:30 to 11 P.M. on CBS, will be simulcast by 50 country-music radio stations.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 17 Mike Bossy, whose 122 goals are the most scored by any player in his first two seasons in the National Hockey League, signed a three-year contract today with the New York Islanders.

ELGIN, Ill., Sept. 17 (Reuters) The McGraw-Edison Company announced today that 95 percent of the outstanding common stock of Studebaker-Worthington Inc. had been tendered to it under its $51.50-a-share takeover offer. The $721 million offer by McGraw-Edison, an electrical prodacts company, had expired last Friday.

But Dr. Subramaniam achieved a delicate balance...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Senator Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma, urged today that Senate action on the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union be postponed until next year pending a "reappraisal" of foreign and defense policy.
PEKING, Sept. 17 Richard M. Nixon arrived tonight in Peking, the scene of what was perhaps his greatest triumph as President, for a four-day visit.
BAHRAIN, Sept. 17 (Reuters) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will begin consultations next month on policy coordination, the Saudi Press Agency said today.

GLASGOW James Lindsay, a 52year-old electrician, stood watching a tide of men in blue coveralls dashing from the old Govan shipyard for lunch as he recited the famous names: Harland Wolff, Fairfield, Inglis and Upper Clyde, the consortium that wound up with John Brown, producer of the three mighty Queens.

The city's federally funded Health Systems Agency recommended yesterday that the Metropolitan Hospital Center on the lower fringes of East Harlem remain open. The planning agency's proposal ran directly counter to a plan by Mayor Koch to close the hospital.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 17 At opposite ends of the locker room at the Jets' practice camp today, two players accepted without question their uncertain status, indicating that Coach Walt Michaels's iron grip on the young team was as strong as ever.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP) Roger Metzger's two-run triple capped a five-run first-inning that carried the San Francisco Giants over the Cincinnati Reds, 7-4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) The Agriculture Department today announced the sale by private exporters of 200,000 metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union. The latest sales brought total Russian grain purchases for the fourth year, which begins Oct. 1, of a five-year wheat agreement to 6.63 million tons, including 3.96 million tons of wheat and 2.67 million tons of corn.

Carl Yastrzemski, who last week became only the 15th major league player to reach the 3,000-hit plateau, yesterday was named the American League's player of the week. The milestone single was Yastrzemski's only hit of the week.

William F. Niehous, the Owens-Illinois executive who spent more than three years as a captive of leftist Venezuelan guerrillas, returned to work yesterday at the company's headquarters in Toledo, Ohio, and made it clear that his main desire was to get on with his job. "I want to start living a normal life," he said.

Funeral services for Abe Murdock, a torrner United States Democratic Senator from Utah, will be held on Friday in the Beaver Mormon 3d-4th Ward Church chapel, Beaver, Utah. Mr. Murdock died Saturday in a Bethesda, Md., hospital. He was 86 years old.

The chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, Edward L. Sadowsky, charged yesterday that delays in New York City's capital-construction program suggested that agency heads were "fiddling while the city crumbles." He said he would propose changes to expedite projects.

The Allied Chemical Corporation said that about 400 employees at its headquarters in Morris Township, N.J., would lose their jobs in a major reorganization of the company. The company also said that about 300 additional employees at 35 other locations would be discharged as well.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Robert S. Strauss, the special American envoy to the Middle East, said today that he would play an active role as a "primary strategist" and fund-raiser in President Carter's re-election campaign.

LONG BEACH, Calif. (UPI) The DC10 jetliner, which was grounded by the Federal Aviation Administration for a time this year, has rebounded to carry more passengers in the month of August than in any previous month in its history, according to the plane's manufacturer.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 18 (UPI) Three explosions rocked a National Guard armory west of San Juan late today and a National Guard truck was burned.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 17 (AP) The two consecutive 300 games bowled by Roger Twiss last week have been disallowed.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 17 (AP) Nigeria has informed its crude oil contract customers that a $3 to $5 special premium will be charged above the official prices set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries beginning Oct. 1, the usually authoritative Middle East Economic Survey has reported.

FOUR a pianist of formidable attainments, James Dick doesn't seem to turn up in New York very frequently. His recital Sunday night at the 92d Street Y was his first local solo appearance in three seasons.

The Trans World Corporation, the parent company of Trans World Airlines, said that its earnings for the JulyAugust period fell to $34.7 million, or $1.96 a share, from $62 million, or $3.66 a share, in the same period last year.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 Mike Hargrove did more than his share for Cleveland tonight as the Indians won a doubleheader from the Yankees, 5-1 and 6-5.

The story tells much about the tyrannical old F.B.I, the conscientious new one, and how Congress needs to shore up the latter.

SUBIC BAY, Philippines, Sept. 17 (Reuters) United States Navy vessels landed 65 Vietnamese refugees at the naval base here today, and a plane spotted 9 others drifting in an open boat in the South China Sea, a naval spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Congress took up the Federal budget for next year today and immediately began debating which groups should bear the burden for fighting inflation. In the process, the lawmakers demonstrated how difficult it is to impose fiscal restraint at a time when every special interest in the capital is fighting to bear as little of the burden as possible.

In a follow-up to the election last month of three vice chairmen and apparent heir apparents for the top job, the General Electric Company announced yesterday the appointment of five executive vice presidents, effective Oct. 1. These executives, who had been senior vice presidents, will be the only ones holding the title of executive vice president.
ROME, Sept. 15 When Pope John Paul II sets out on his journey to Ireland and the United States, he will take a flying "little Vatican" with him.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept.17 (AP) The defense in the murder retrial of Huey Newton, a former leader of the Black Panther Party, abruptly rested its case today, contending that the prosecution had failed to prove that Mr. Newton killed Kathleen Smith in 1974.
The Cosmos left yesterday for a five-week tour of the Far East that will include 12 exhibition matches.

DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Sept. 17 (Reuters) West Germany's current monetary policy risks weakening the United States dollar and forcing the Federal Reserve Board to take countermeasures that have serious conseauences for the world economy,

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The gasoline-supply disruptions of last spring and ever-increasing costs have prompted many police departments across the country to turn to more fuel-efficient patrol cars, to handle more cases by telephone and to dispatch more foot patrols, a check of departments has shown.

Man's quest for other solar systems capable of habitation by intelligent beings is hindered by the relatively puny power of the instruments with which he confronts the immensity of space. But an astronomer at Stanford University has proposed the idea of a telescope 205 billion miles long that could do the job.

Charles Darwin remains the bete noire of fundamentalist Christians who, 120 years after publication of "The Origin of Species," insist that biology textbooks pay attention to the activity of a supernatural Creator.

The Commodities Futures Trading Commission disclosed in Washington yesterday that the United States Justice Department had withdrawn its objection to the proposed merger of the New York Cocoa Exchange with the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

The rear door and tail cone of an Air Canada DC-9 twin-jet airliner were ripped away high over the Atlantic yesterday and assorted parcels and a food cart were swept out through the gaping hole, but the plane was able to land safely with no serious injuries to the 43 persons on board.

DENVER, Sept. 17 The House of Bishops, one of two legislative bodies of the Episcopal Church, overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today holding that homosexuals have an equal claim with others upon the love, acceptance and pastoral concern of the church but should not be ordained as priests.

LONDON, Sept. 17 The price of gold soared above $350 an ounce for the first time today, with some dealers saying the end of the spectacular climb was nowhere in sight.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 This year, for the first time, California has surpassed New York as the state with the most lawyers. But that distinction may be dubious because there are several indications that more lawyers are out of work in California than anywhere else.

General Growth Properties, a real estate investment trust based in Des Moines, said that it had agreed to sell 10 of its shopping centers to the Aetna Life Insurance Company for $90 million in cash and about $70 million in mortgage debt. The sale should result in a capital gain distribution of about $15 a share, the company said.

TOKYO, Sept. 17 Beginning what promises to be a spirited contest turning mostly on financial issues, nearly 900 aspirants for the 511 seats in the House of Representatives registered as candidates today as national electoral authorities proclaimed the official opening of the campaign for elections Oct. 7.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) Joseph P. Richardson, a prominent architect, died Friday at his home in Brookline. He was 66 years old.

Fifty years ago this fall, the stock market crashed, leading the country into the Great Depression. In our mythological memory it was a great crash, in a single day, with people leaping out windows on Wall Street. In fact, it was nothing of the kind. The incidence of suicide, for instance, was probably lower than average. The stock market did not crash in a single day.

The 1979 World Junior Championship in Skien, Norway, was won by Yasser Seirawan, an 18-year-old Seattle master. He led a Swiss system field of 56 contenders with a score of 10-3, with eight victories, one loss and four draws.

Chaim Shlome Kazdan, a longtime member of the Jewish Labor Bund, and a writer and educator, died Saturday at the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 96 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

The Securities Industry Association has disbanded its 70-member governing council in the first major restructuring of the trade association since it was established in 1972. The move to streamline the S.I.A. structure was made at a meeting of the board of directors in Atlanta Monday.

In a move viewed as a precursor to increases in the prime rate, the Bankers Trust Company raised to 13 percent yesterday the interest rate it charges securities dealers to finance their customers' margin accounts.
