Women will get three of the four nominations in Queens for State Supreme Court justice, Democratic political leaders said yesterday.

IT does not take an expert to know that the best New York apartment houses are old ones. Almost every newcomer to such buildings as the Dakota, the Beresford or 998 Fifth Avenue comes away muttering something to the effect that they don't make them like that anymore. Even the casual observer can see that smaller rooms, thinner walls, lower ceilings and surfaces devoid of detail do not make the architectural history books.

On the street outside the funeral home at 1 Troy Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn where they had come to pay their respects to Police Officer Melvin E. Hopkins, 5,000 policeman stood silently in formation as the funeral procession made its way slowly past them and out to the Calverton National Cemetery on Long Island.

Max L. Friedman, former president of the A.S. Beck Shoe Corporation and a benefactor and charter member of the board of overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.
HOUSTON, Sept. 19--As the Dalai Lama listened intently, a widely varied group of 13 panelists today debated the relationship between contemplation and action in the Eastern and Western worlds.
The credit markets scored substantial gains yesterday, cutting short the downward trend in fixed-income prices that began late Tuesday after the Federal Reserve increased the discount rate.

A state legislative investigating committee reported yesterday that it had found that nearly two-thirds of the gasoline stations it covered in a survey in New York City charged more than the new maximum prices allowed by Federal law.
MARION, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP)-- Anthony Meril of Dallas skippered the winning boat to 14 points and the national championship in the Shields OneDesign Class races which ended here today.

BRUSSELS, Sept 19 (Reuters)--The European Economic Community will achieve its goal of cutting daily oil consumption 5 percent by the end of this year, E.E.C. officials said today. But they expect crude oil consumption by the nine Common Market nations for all 1979 to be well above the target set last March.

IT was the first dress rehearsal of Verdi's "Otello," which will open the Metropolitan Opera's 93d season Monday night. The cast was on stage in costumes and makeup: Placido Domingo as Otello in his sumptuous robes of gold and black and Gilda Cruz-Romo as Desdemona in a gown of pale blue satin trimmed with pearls.

The Israelis keep nibbling at the political status quo in the West Bank territory and then ask the world to believe that their modest maneuvers and settlements have no great bearing on the issues on which peace there will finally depend. The United States, Egypt and others are expected to protest, but Jerusalem proceeds as if the erosion of Arab claims is costfree so long as it develops in slow motion.

Frankly, we admire the electrifying smiles of Robert Abrams, the Attorney General of the State of New York. We admire also the energy he marshals for his busy office. But last week, having observed what struck us as one big smile too many, we began to feel that the responsibilities of an Attorney General include abstinence as well as commitment.

A group of New York players has been mopping up titles in regional championships this month, first in Montreal and then in Puerto Rico. Kathie Wei won four events, David Berkowitz three, and Mamie Lee, Judy Tucker, Alan Sontag, Harold Lilie and Jim Becker two each.

New York City officials no longer believe that the municipal hospital closings proposed by Mayor Koch will be carried out in the face of the intense opposition they have generated among black and Hispanic constituencies in the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Canadian Government is not likely to help the Chrysler Corporation's Canadian subsidiary until it sees what steps the United States takes to help the ailing auto company, a high-ranking Canadian official said today.

The board of directors of the Trans World Corporation, the parent company of Trans World Airlines, joined the company's management yesterday in opposing plans by Texas International Airlines to gain control of T.W.A.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--At 14th and K Streets, a few blocks from the White House, in several floors of nondescript offices with neither a title on the door nor a carpet on the floor, the Carter-Mondale Presidential Committee is plotting strategy, organizing workers and raising money to win a second term for Jimmy Carter.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 19 (AP)--The men's Olympic basketball team from the Soviet Union plans to visit the United States in November for a coast-to-coast tour against 14 collegiate teams. The tour schedule, released yesterday by the Amateur Basketball Association of the United States of America, is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for five runs in the ninth inning, capped by Manny Sanguillen's game-winning pinch triple, to beat the Phillies, 9-6, in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader today, then saw Philadelphia rally for a 6-5 triumph in the second game.

Anthony Industries Inc. said that the Shakespeare Company's board had agreed to merge its company into a subsidiary of Anthony Industries after Anthony raised its bid to about $40 million from $38 million.

MY mother died last month. She was my closest friend. She was also my father's closest friend, and his dream-sharer, his adviser on family policy, his unwill ing but able first mate when they sailed, his sense of direction when he drove, his childhood sweetheart, his muse, his best audience, much more.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 (AP)--Johnny Bench belted a two-run homer to lead Cincinnati to a 3-2 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight and increase the Reds' lead to 2 games over the Houston Astros in the National League West.
HONG KONG, Sept. 19 (Reuters)-- Hong Kong officials report a four-day lull in the arrival of Vietnamese refugees, saying that no "boat people" had landed here since a group of 415 came Saturday.

Charles J. Donahue, professor emeritus of English at Fordham University, died Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and a resident of Eastchester, N.Y.
Andrew J. Stein says he has become leery about running as part of a Carter-forPresident ticket.

A special squad of 40 police officers in cars, vans, scooters and a helicopter carried out a citywide roundup yesterday of members of what law enforcement officials called "a multimillion-dollar loansharking operation that was attempting to take over white-collar businesses."

A QUARTET of fantasies made up the piano recital by Manuel Delaflor in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. This is not a new idea, but it remains an intriguing one, and it provided a fillip to this return appearance by the Mexican artist. Included in the program were Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue, the Schumann Fantasy, the Chopin Fantasy and Schubert's "Wanderer" Fantasy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19-- The Soviet Union lost a diplomatic skirmish today when the Credentials Committee voted 6 to 3 against removing Pol Pot's representative from the Cambodian seat in the General Assembly.
Sotheby Parke Bernet and Citibank have entered an agreement for the British-based auction house to act as a consultant to the bank on purchases of art and antiques.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Sept. 19--The development board of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission approved a slightly scaled-down plan today for a $1 billion commercial shopping center, office building and housing complex known as Berry's Creek Center.

A special tax adjustment by Britain swelled net income of the Seagram Company by $75.6 million but distorted its results for the quarter and fiscal year ended July 31, according to the report yesterday by the world's largest distiller.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 19--One person was killed today and at least 58 injured when a bomb exploded during evening rush hour at a crowded pedestrian mall in the heart of Jerusalem.

Gold and silver prices, which have shown sharp gains in recent weeks, took time out for a breather yesterday in the American commodities markets as well as in Europe. Most market participants, however, were not yet ready to say that the upward spiral has run its course.

BURKE, Va.--For most of us, but particularly Bostonians, Gilbert Stuart's matched George and Martha Washington portraits--the Athenaeum portraits--are more than simply fine examples of early American art. While our $1 bill popularized the artist's paternalistic portrayal of a national hero for all to enjoy, the Bostonians, in whose city the pair have hung for over 100 years, consider them part of their historical heritage.

Giorgio Mazzanti became chairman of Ente Nationale Idrocarburi, Italy's giant state-owned oil company, on Feb. 1--right in the midst of the Iranian oil shutdown. Italy was in trouble. The multinational oil companies were announcing significant supply cutbacks, and Italy's smaller, private oil companies were especially strapped.

The Gateway Sporting Goods Company said that results of the geological survey of part of its leased Zulu Mine in Gila County, Ariz., disclosed indications of substantial reserves of gold on one of the five claims on the property. The Zulu mine was worked in the 1930's and was shut down at the beginning of World War II.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 19--An order of Roman Catholic nuns that has ministered for more than a century to the people of the Appalachian coal fields filed suit today against the Blue Diamond Coal Company, saying it would seek to force "corporate responsibility" on the mine operator.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19--Jolted earlier in the day by the loss of Willie Mays Aikens, the California Angels suffered two further setbacks tonight.

A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, was excessive in his compensation to the Seattle SuperSonics for the New York Knicks' signing last September of Marvin Webster, a free agent who had been with Seattle.

Amateur carpenters, woodworkers, interior designers, clothes makers and auto mechanics may find subjects to help them with their current projects among the cornucopia of courses offered in the metropolitan area this fall.
HOURS after a fire killed nine people and injured 78 at a Holiday Inn in Cambridge, Ohio, fire officials were blaming the motel's quite legal lack of smoke detectors for the scale of the disaster.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)--A House-Senate conference committee agreed today on the final version of an Amtrak authorization bill that would kill five long-distance trains but preserve two lightly patronized lines across West Virginia.
BONN, Sept. 19 (AP)--The West German Government nominated Karl Otto Poehl today as the next president of the Bundesbank, the country's Frankfurt-based central bank.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (UPI)--Ozark Air Lines, shut down by a flight attendants' strike, today canceled all regular flights through Monday. A spokesman said the airline would cancel an additional day for each day the strike continues because it will take at least four days for union members to vote when a tentative agreement is reached, and two additional days for the airline to prepare planes for flights. The attendants struck Friday.

A delegation of black political and civilrights leaders are scheduled to meet Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance this morning to urge him to seek "massive increases" in American aid to Africa in coming years.

An 81-year-old man was seriously wounded yesterday during a bank robbery in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, reportedly after begging one of the two robbers not to hurt anyone. The wounded man was identified as Ben Joseph of Riverdale.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Sept. 19 (AP) --Motorists lining up for the relatively inexpensive gas at the Exxon service stations on the Garden State Parkway have forced the company to set a $3 limit on purchases, the New Jersey Highway Authority said today.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19--The Jets acted today against Bob Martin, their only player who had acknowledged being unhappy. They dropped him.
BACK in the 1920's, Alfred P. Sloan, the guiding spirit of General Motors, invented planned obsolescence as a marketing aid. And to make sure that his products became obsolete quickly...

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19--The United States Ambassador here has broken a taboo that had endured since the Korean war by using in public the official name of North Korea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. The South Korean Government, unhappy with the action, protested to the American Embassy.
Two more oil companies responded yesterday to President Carter's request to hold prices of heating oil at current levels.
Alden C. Smith, a former member of Price Waterhouse Company's executive committee and once a Mayor of Scarsdale, died Tuesday at the age of 76 in Naples, Fla., where he had been living.

PEKING, Sept. 19 (AP)--Former President Richard M. Nixon met today with Prime Minister Hua Guofeng, who called the visitor "an old friend" and said he was looking better than when they first met in 1976.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 19-- Venezuela, one of the most important suppliers of foreign oil to the United States East Coast, announced today that it would reduce production of crude oil next year by 6 percent and exports by 7 percent.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Sept. 17--Paul Engle was being corrected by his wife: "Don't say, 'the Taiwanese poet.' Say 'the poet from Taiwan,' or 'from the mainland.' Otherwise it sounds like two different countries, and the Chinese believe Taiwan is just a province. On both sides, they believe that."

The Knicks said yesterday that they had signed Earl Monroe, the 34year-old backcourt man who will be entering his 13th season in the National Basketball Asssociation, to a one-year contract estimated to be worth $250,000.

LONDON, Sept. 19--While black and white delegates to the peace conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia here haggle over a constitution, the killing at home continues at the rate of at least one more victim shot, axed or burned to death every hour. The death toll for the seven years of war is now over 20,000, almost a third killed this year.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP)-- Three life-size statues valued at $24,000 and depicting SS. Peter, Paul and John were stolen from the Kensico Cemetery here some time between Monday night and yesterday morning, the police reported.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 19 (Reuters)--Travelers from Afghanistan said on reaching Pakistan today that the new Afghan President, Hafizullah Amin, came to power over the weekend despite an ambush intended to kill him.

A Family Day celebration opens a major children's architectural exhibition Sunday at the Newark Museum with exhibits ranging from historic objects of the 18th century to imaginative concepts by present day artists. The activities take place from noon to 5 P.M.

"A Time to Die," Tom Wicker's book about the 1971 uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in upstate New York, is being turned into a two-hour made-for-television movie entitled "Attica." It will be broadcast on ABCTV this season on date to be announced.

Wien Air Alaska Inc. announced it had filed a petition with the Civil Aeronautics Board requesting the board to reconsider an Aug. 24 order that, among other things, granted Alaska Airlines authority to operate in competition with Wien along a certain route.

The Chemical Bank raised its prime lending rate to 13 percent from 13 percent yesterday, one day after the Federal Reserve System raised its discount rate and signaled still greater monetary restraint.

Elsewhere in the futures markets, interest rate contracts, following a rise in the discount and target interest rates by the Federal Reserve, rose in all but spot deliveries, with some Treasury bill futures briefly gaining as much as the 50-point daily trading limit. An analyst said a general expectation that interest rates would soon peak encouraged the rally.

AUGUSTA, Sicily, Sept. 19 (Reuters) --Hundreds of people in this port town went on a one-day strike today to protest air and sea pollution by coastal industries. The protest was aimed at a huge Esso refinery and two plants producing chemicals, blamed by city officials for pollution that killed 15 tons of fish this month.

ST. LOUIS--The next six weeks of performances of the St. Louis Symphony, including a West Coast tour and two recording sessions, have been canceled after efforts failed to resolve a twoweek strike by musicians.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (Reuters)-- The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it planned to double total production of polyvinyl chloride at its Pedricktown, N.J., plants to about 350 million pounds a year as part of a previously announced six-year expansion plan for polyvinyl chloride in North America.

ENTEBBE, Uganda, Sept. 19--Andrew Young made an unscheduled stop today in Entebbe at the invitation of Uganda's President and heard his host appeal for American financial aid for the reconstruction of the "war-devastated country."

The Eastmet Corporation, a metal distributor, said that it had begun its previously proposed tender offer for one million common shares of the U.I.P. Corporation, makers of castings and plastics, in a $20 million transaction.

ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Sept. 19 (UPI)--Nick Mike-Mayer was signed today by the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League, becoming the seventh place-kicker to make the club's regular-season roster in the last four years. To make room him, Coach Chuck Knox released Tom Dempsey, who kicked for the Bills last season and in the first three games this year.

The Conference Board announced yesterday that its measure of business confidence, based on a survey of more than 1,600 chief executives across the nation, had dropped to its lowest level since it was created in early 1976.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--A skittish House, after first approving a 7 percent, or $4,025, Congressional pay increase in a nonrecorded vote today, reversed itself when opponents of the raise forced it into voting on the record.

Preston Jones, author of "A Texas Trilogy," died yesterday in Dallas after having undergone surgery for ulcers. He was 43 years old. Mr. Jones was an actor as well as playwright with Paul Baker's Dallas Theater Center.

Sanford D. Garelik will remain as director of security for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority only until the end of the year, John D. Simpson, the M.T.A.'s executive director, said last night. Mr. Simpson had indicated that Mr. Garelik would stay on indefinitely, after he was ousted as chief of the Transit Police last week.

Residents of a Fifth Avenue luxury building filed suit yesterday seeking to block former President Richard M. Nixon from buying an apartment, saying the presence of the Secret Service would disrupt their peace and quiet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)--The Civil Aeronautics Board moved today to end a practice under which an industry group determines the rates that travel agents receive as commissions for selling airline tickets.
A 32-year-old Queens woman fatally shot her two small children early yesterday, then shot herself in the chest, according to the police.

WEST BERLIN, Sept. 19--When an explosion in a Hamburg suburb killed a small boy and maimed two of his playmates earlier this month, it seemed like one of those tragic accidents in which World War II munitions and explosives still occasionally kill people decades after the end of the war.

BANFF, Alberta, Sept. 19--Ontario will continue to buy large volumes of coal from the United States, according to Robert Welch, the province's Energy Minister, indicating an apparent reversal of earlier policy that had envisaged rising volumes of both steam and metallurgical coal supplied from western Canadian mines.

New York City's Comptroller has told a group of homosexual business leaders that "it might make sense--dollars and cents--to include the gay community in the national promotion of New York City as a tourist attraction."
ALBANY, Sept. 19 (AP)--The highest court of New York State has dismissed a $50 million lawsuit filed by Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, against Henry Ford 2d and the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)--Oil and gas companies must include a separate financial summary of their oil-and gas-producing activities in their annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission under a plan approved by the agency today. The commission originally proposed the requirement a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)-- President Carter today proclaimed Oct. 3 as National Day of Prayer. In a proclamation pursuant to a 1952 law, the President said, "We accept our responsibilities and make our choices with all the will and determination at our command, but always in the full knowledge that we are finally in the hands of God."

PARIS, Sept. 19--A group of young intellectuals collectively called "The New Right," held a news conference this week to explain their ideology. They denounced egalitarianism, Christian ideology and "American imperialism" and called for a return to the antique origins of European culture.

RED GARLAND, the elusive pianist who has spent most of the years since his mid-50's tenure with the Miles Davis Quintet quietly playing in Dallas, is at the Village Vanguard this week. He's been there twice before since he reemerged a little over a year ago with some new recordings for the Galaxy label, but this time he's brought his own quartet along from Texas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)--Senator William Proxmire said today that the staff of his Senate Banking Committee had found no evidence that John B. Connally had used improper influence in granting national bank charters when he was Treasury Secretary.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 20 Directors of the St. Andrew's Golf Club, the oldest in the country, have negotiated an agreement with Jack Nicklaus under which the champion golfer would redesign the course to attract major tournaments and build condominiums on the club property.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 In a narrow, white-painted brownstone near the Capitol, a Roman Catholic priest from Northern Ireland, a Belfast housewife and a lawyer with the United States Customs Service have quietly begun an ambitious and controversial drive seeking American support for the withdrawal of...

The Gillette Company said it had agreed to acquire the Liquid Paper Corporation for about $47.5 million in cash. Liquid Paper, which is privately held, earned more than $3.5 million on sales of $38 million in its fiscal year ended April 30.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20In a ritual as old as the United Nations, the flag of the small Caribbean island of St. Lucia was hoisted to the top of a 22-foot pole yesterday, in an outdoor ceremony honoring the newest member of the world organization.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20 Senior United States and Mexican officials held talks today aimed at reaching, agreement on Mexican sales of natural gas to the United States before President Jose Lopez Portillo pays an official visit to Washington next week.
The Major League Umpires Association accused the National League yesterday of unfair labor practices involving salaries and fringe benefits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Administration officials said today that talks with the Soviet Union about its reported combat brigade in Cuba had taken a new turn, with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance offering ideas for the first time on how to resolve the problem, which has jeopardized Senate approval of the strategic arms treaty.

PHILADELPHIA Pope John Paul II, whose six-city tour of the United States is less than two weeks away, and John Cardinal Krol, the Archbishop of Philadelphia, have been accused of helping to cover up a scandal involving the Pauline Fathers.
Stock prices soared yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average scored its biggest advance since last November. A boom in oil issues set the tone for the boisterous market.

A NEW series with the improbable title of "Eischied" (pronounced Eye-shyed) offers tall, heavyset Joe Don Baker as Earl Eischied, Chief of Detectives in New York City. If Kojack had his lollypops, Eischied puffs on big cigars and...

If you believe in lasers, putting your faith in a fairy will be a lot easier this year. The fairy is Tinkerbell, the smallest star of the current Broadway production of "Peter Pan," at the LuntFontanne Theater. Tink is a laser beam, filtered, bent, oscillated and endowed with a certain undeniable personality by her creators, Laser Media Inc.

LOS ANGELES CALIFORNIA has long been the home of legal innovations. Early in the 1970's, it was the birthplace of storefront "legal clinics" that merchandise law on as assembly-line basis. The latest bright idea W emerge from the state is the law yerless law office. And that development could have significant business consequences for banks and retail stores.

The Mills family, descendants of wealthy financiers and philanthropists, owned five palatial homes in France, California, Rhode Island, New York City and in Hyde Park, two hours north of the city, overlooking the Hudson River. They always occupied their...

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 20 (AP) Federal officials said today that they had expanded their investigation of possible contamination by the banned chemical PCB to meat-packing plants and feed lot operations in some Western and Middle Western states.
A judge in New York dismissed an injunction yesterday against James Dines, the California-based publisher of a newsletter that advocates investment in gold and other metals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Following the defeat by the House of Representatives last night of a proposed budget for the fiscal year 1980, the House Budget Committee decided today to try again to present a new budget proposal next week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) The Senate approved legislation today to authorize $33.7 million for Federal water resources programs in the fiscal year 1980.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters) Jose Eduardo dos Santos has assumed the post of President of Angola and of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola after the death of President Agostinho Neto, the Angolan news agency reported from Luanda tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 He was at last in the country he had longed for, where the listeners were sympathetic and knew his language. But he spoke slowly, trying to translate past into present and apologizing when the words would fail.
ROME, Sept. 20 Ten days before his departure for Ireland and the United States, Pope John Paul II is facing labor problems at home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Foreign investors own an interest in about four million acres of United States agricultural land, less than fivetenths of I percent of the 1.05 billion acres owned by farmers and other private citizens, the Agriculture Department said today.
Paul Maze, a French-born artist who had been a painting companion of the late Sir Winston Churchill, died Monday at his home near Midhurst, Sussex, England. He was 92 years old.
The 125 savings and loan associations in New York State experienced a net inflow of $18 million in savings during August, the Savings League Association of New York reported yesterday.
ONE wants to squeeze James Baldwin's new novel like a sponge, to wring its neck of excess adjectives, repetitions, digressions, sermonettes and self-regard. "Just Above My Head" is such a....
A four-day strike at Lefrak City that disrupted services and left some buildings with accumulations of trash and flooded basements was settled yesterday.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP) Two Nets' rookies, Cliff Robinson and Calvin Natt, sparked a 35-point New Jersey fourth-quarter rally that overtook the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, 102-98, in the first preseason National Basketball Association game for each team. Robinson scored 14 ponts and Natt added 9 in the period.

Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Empire, who had ruled that country autocratically since 1965, was overthrown in a bloodless coup last night, Agence France-Presse reported from Bangui, the capital, citing French Embassy sources.

Our limits today for the unfettered indulgence of emotion are more rigid than ever before because unless we take heed of those limits we risk the destruction of ourselves and our planet. So far, women have been able...

The emotional debate over the Panama Canal treaties perhaps the most controversial fight in American foreign policy since the Vietnam War reached a crescendo with the Senate's approval of them last year, but sparring over carrying out the treaties and over what they mean has continued virtually without letup.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Federal Communications Commission charged today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been selling private-line telephone services to high-volume users at "unjust, unreasonable and unlawful rates" that are subsidized by ordinary telephone users.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A White House directive on how to handle future negotiations with Moscow has led Administration arms control experts to question whether the President is reducing his commitment to seek further constraints on Soviet and American military forces.

THE last words spoken from the stage of Madison Square Gar den Wednesday night, at the first of five benefit concerts for the antinuclear movement sponsored by Musicians United for Safe Energy, were Graham Nash's: "We can do it."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 To the dismay of some supporters here, Vice President Mondale attracted only 200 northern Californians to a $200-a-plate luncheon for the Carter-Mondale Re-election Committee today. The total included holders of 50 tickets that were sold last night for $10 or were given away.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--President Carter moved today to restore service on the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, which has been shut down by a strike that has halted part of the nation's grain shipments from the Middle West.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 (UPI) Striking nurses have ended their sevenday-old walkout at the state medical center in Cranston. The decision came only hours after a judge threatened stiff fines if the strike did not end by today.

The Transit Authority has determined that Anthony V. Bouza deputy chief of the transit police under Sanford D. Garelik until both were removed at the Mayor's request 10 days ago is not entitled to the $20,000 he had sought as reimbursement for unused vacation days and overtime.
PRAGUE, Sept. 20 (UPI) Ludvik Svohoda, a former President of Czechoslovakia, died today of a heart attack following a long illness. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 In a surprise action, the House defeated by 11 votes today a bill that would carry out the terms of the Panama Canal Treaty.

William Montella Jr., who operated a waterfront company, testified yesterday that he wore a concealed tape recorder at a 1978 meeting when he gave "an envelope containing $5,000" to Anthony M. Scotto, a top leader of the International Longshoremen's Association.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP) Coach Ted Marchibroda of the Baltimore Colts today cut his place-kicker, Toni Linhart, despite protests from the club's owner, who had given Linhart a $10,000 raise after a poor performance last Sunday.

A prudent London bookmaker would set long odds for the success of Britain's latest Rhodesian peacemaking effort. One British Government after another has insisted that settlement was within reach. Each time, the angry rivals marched home to resume what has become a brutal, and widening, civil war. That is still the result that the prudent gambler would find most likely. But at least this time there are stirrings.

LONDON, Sept. 20 Agreement on a new independence constitution for Zimbabwe Rhodesia is "very close," the country's Foreign' Minister, David Mukome, asserted today as the Lancaster House negotiations approached the end of their second week.

SANTURCE, Spain, Sept. 20 (UPI) The police reported today that three bombs had exploded in a stationary freight train carrying a consignment for the French automaker Renault. They said the bombs destroyed part of the load and damaged two of the train's seven carriages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Soviet officials have decided to close a Russian art exhibition at the Renwick Gallery seven weeks early, an apparent reaction to the gallery's scheduling of a recital by a defector from the Bolshoi Opera.

DETER MAAS, author of "The Valachi Papers" and "Serpico," first met Frank Costello, the so-called "Prime Minister of the Underworld," in 1962 while working on a magazine piece. During the next few years, whenever he ran into...
A free, outdoor performance will be given by the Big Apple Dance Theater tomorrow at 1 P.M. on Pier 84, on the Hudson River, at the foot of 44th Street.
IN "Yanks," 27-year-old Lisa Eichhorn makes her screen debut as a shy English shopgirl who falls in love with an American soldier during World War II.

ANDRZEJ WASOWSKI, a Polish pianist who made a considerable splash in Europe right after World War II and has demonstrated a distinctive style in his few appearances here, gave an absorbing recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The Storer Broadcasting Company said it had obtained $120 million in longterm financing to be used primarily for...

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 20 (AP) Gov. Fob James went on statewide television tonight to urge Alabamians to contribute nonperishable food to areas of south Alabama that were devastated last week by Hurricane Frederic.

TERESINA, Brazil, Sept. 18 The Brazilian Government has just launched its most ambitious effort to aid the semiarid impoverished Brazilian northeast, but residents here are reacting to it the way New Yorkers greet perennial proposals to clean up Times Square.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) Lack of confidence in United States economic policies sent the dollar plummeting on world money markets today, with analysts predicting that more losses might be on the way. Gold prices hit record levels in Europe but slipped in New York after an early surge.

Still battered and bruised from Monday night's game, Joe Pisarcik, the Giant quarterback, was unable to practice yesterday, and that made it likely that Randy Dean would start Sunday afternoon against the Philadelphia Eagles at Giants Stadium.

A supply supervisor for Pan American World Airways was shot to death outside his Wantagh, L.I., home yesterday morning. Within hours, Federal agents said they were investigating a possible connection between the slaying and the recently uncovered theft of Pan Am navigational computers valued at $3 million.

The New England-San Diego game at Foxboro, Mass., on Sunday heads the National Football League schedule. It matches two teams selected as division favorites in preseason estimates, and they are at or near the top in important statistical considerations.

At the same time that the police were penetrating a multimillion-dollar loanshark operation that preyed on businessmen, members of the ring were trying to infiltrate the Bronx District Attorney's office to obtain information about the investigation.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 For the second time in little more than a year, the Argentine Supreme Court has ruled that Jacobo Timerman, the former newspaper publisher who has been detained without charges since April 1977, should be set free.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 20 Just when they were beginning to look like candidates for the emergency ward, the California Angels bounced back to health tonight with an 11-6 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

WASHINGTON, Sept.20 President Carter's energy legislation showed signs of movement in Congress today, as the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee completed work on a bill creating a mobilization board to speed construction of experimental projects.

WEST BERLIN, Sept. 20 East Germany's Communist Party leader says that his country and the Soviet Union are strengthening and modernizing their military capabilities in Central Europe in a move to counter Atlantic alliance plans for emplacing new nuclear missiles in West Germany.

Dennis C. Stanfill, chairman and president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, confirmed yesterday that his company was engaged "in serious discussions" with Alan J. Hirschfield, former president and chief executive of Columbia Pictures Industries, to "come to Fox in a very senior position." Mr. Hirschfield is currently a consultant to Warner Communications Inc.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 24 More than seven years of military rule formally ended in Ghana today as an elected President and a 140-member civilian Parliament were sworn in amid applause, a 21gun salute and a warning.

BANGUI, Central African Republic, Sept. 24 David Dacko, President of one of the 25 poorest countries in the world, said today that he would move to establish diplomatic and trade relations with South Africa if that nation could help improve the economic situation here.

ATLANTA, Sept. 24 (UPI) Eddie Solomon pitched a five-hitter and Gary Matthews drove in four runs tonight to lead the Atlanta Braves to an 8-1 victory over Houston and complete a doubleheader sweep that jolted the Astros' division championship chances.
VENICE, Sept. 24 (AP) A high tide and strong winds brought flooding to some sections of Venice today. The water was reported nearly 3.3 feet above the pavement in the worst-hit areas.

Those who insist that it's all right for Federal judges to belong to white-only social clubs had better look around. Their stand is now to the right of Strom Thurmond, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 The largest number of blacks, Hispanic people and women ever to enter the State Police Academy reported for duty today.

MATHEMATICIANS and educators warned last week that reports of students' declining performance in mathematics may touch off "reforms" that will make the problem worse. In interviews, they expressed the view that pressures to increase classroom drill and prepare students for minimum competency tests will further erode students' capacity to use mathematics to solve problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Anthony M. Solomon, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that he expected the dollar to grow stronger as a result of improvements projected in the balance of payments and the inflation rate and the upward revaluation of the West German mark.

DUBLIN It was his 12th-century predecessor Adrian IV who started it all by making a gift of Ireland to the British crown; but John Paul II will be the first Pope in the eight centuries since then to set foot on this divided island when he arrives here later this week. To many of this devoutly Roman Catholic country's 3 million people, his visit is the event of a lifetime.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) The McDonnell Douglas Corporation today announced $155 million in orders from two airlines for two of its problemplagued models the DC-10 jumbo jet and the DC-9. Mexicana Airlines signed an $85 million contract to purchase two DC-10's for delivery in 1981, and Midway Airlines signed a $70 million agreement for five DC-9 jets and the leasing of five more, McDonnell Douglas said.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 24 A New Haven nursing home that is partly owned by a Hartford Congressman is the subject of an investigation involving its treatment of patients and its physical facilities, a state official says.

The Exxon Corporation, unable to reach mutually satisfactory terms with the Federal Trade Commission over its offer to purchase the Reliance Electric Company, announced yesterday that it had broken off negotiations with the Government agency and had bought Reliance anyway.
"If you drive in Manhattan on Oct. 2 or 3, you're not only not going to get where you're going; you're not going to be able to get back to where you came from," a police spokesman said yesterday.

If asked to vote for the world's most interesting tournament, many knowledgeable votes would go to Deauville in France, staged annually in July. The main event this year was almost a miniworld championship, for it was an invitation team event with two groups from North America and one each from France, Italy and the Netherlands.
NANA MOUSKOURI has fashioned a bland but interesting hybrid out of the Western world's popular and folk musics.

Roy R. Silver, a reporter for The New York Times who had been with the newspaper 38 years, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Mr. Silver, who lived in Freeport, L.I., was stricken Sunday while visiting friends. He would have been 61 years old on Thursday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 In a decision that may have far-reaching implications in other cities, a Federal district judge ruled today that patronage hiring for city and county jobs here, the base of the Democratic Party's power in Chicago, is unconstitutional.

In common with all birds, the extinct moa, an ostrich-like runner that sometimes grew 12 feet tall, ate gravel and pebbles. Birds need grinding material in their crops, which serve the same function as the teeth used by other animals for chewing food.

With quiet help from representatives of Mayor Koch, the regular Democrats from the Bronx captured two State Supreme Court nominations last night that the Manhattan organization thought it had sufficient votes to win.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) An underground parking garage near Grant Park, the site of a mass to be said by Pope John Paul II on Oct. 5, can safely withstand the weight of an expected crowd of 1.5 million people, Mayor Jane Byrne said today.
Coast Guard helicopters rescued 16 persons from the Atlantic Ocean off Fire Island last night after their chartered fishing boat hit a submerged object, broke up and sank.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 24 With Nolan Ryan pitching a five-hitter and Dan Ford driving home all their runs, the California Angels advanced to the threshold of a divisional championship tonight.
A major witness for the prosecution testified under cross-examination yesterday that he had sometimes hated Anthony M. Scotto while making cash payments to him.

TORONTO, Sept. 24 Quietly, in the halls of Congress and the conference rooms of Washington, Ottawa, Buffalo and here in Toronto, American and Canadian businessmen are fighting a little-known guerrilla war over an estimated $115 million in international television and tourism business.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 24 Ray Perkins benched his best player yesterday "to teach us a lesson that if you don't practice, you don't play," several Giant veterans said today.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson arrived in Israel today with a plea for talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, and he immediately ran into a wall of tough Israeli argument at a meeting in City Hall.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) The General Motors Corporation recalled all of its new front-wheel drive compacts with automatic transmissions today to fix either fire hazards or steering gear problems.

ALTHOUGH the Internal Revenue Service has attempted to estimate the size of the underground economy transactions strictly for cash on which taxes are not paid the General Accounting Office thinks the figures are too low.

Five hundred teachers in Spokane, Wash., ringed a parking garage to try to block school buses from rolling yesterday, as a walkout resumed at schools in Indianapolis and negotiations remained deadlocked in Detroit.

Orders for machine tools increased in August, little affected by a broad economic slowdown, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. Orders for the machines used in making industrial equipment totaled $429.2 million, up 19 percent from July's $362.1 million and up 15 percent from the $374.8 million of orders in August 1978.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 The Chicago Symphony's musicians have reached a tentative contract agreement with the orchestra's management that would end a six-day strike that forced the cancellation of four preseason concerts.

A passer-by apparently helped himself to more than $2,000 late yesterday afternoon after a bank robbery suspect was tackled by a teller on a busy Manhattan street following the city's eighth bank robbery of the day.

LONDON, Sept. 24 In a significant concession, Zimbabwe Rhodesia's guerrillas formally agreed today to guarantee the country's white minority 20 percent of the seats in Parliament under a new constitution.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 24 (UPI) The deposed Central African emperor, accused of murder in his homeland and denied political refuge in France, flew to this former French colony today and was granted asylum.
THERE seemed to be something special about last night's Metropolitan Opera opening. Perhaps it was the excitement attendant on a great opera, Verdi's "Otello."

The oil industry, after a period of flirtation with acquisitions in unrelated fields, has refocused its attention on the energy field, lured by the prospect of oil-price decontrol and Government incentives for the development of alternative fuels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) In Washington, where there is a Federal bureaucracy for virtually every contingency, there is an agency whose computers can produce long columns showing what disasters cost and which Presidents are openhanded and which are tightfisted in declaring disasters.

Porleaf Benestad, a former senior vice president of the defunct American Bank and Trust Company, has pleaded guilty to a charge of misapplying $8.1 million in bank funds, a felony carrying a maximum penalty of four years in jail.

When Catfish Hunter delivered his valedictory at Yankee Stadium recently, he thanked various people, alive and dead, for his success and his wealth. There were, however, two glaring omissions: he could have mentioned Peter Seitz and he could have mentioned the Major League Baseball Players' Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Government today announced a proposed settlement of antitrust suits that would permit the Beneficial Corporation to acquire most of two smaller loan companies, Capital Financial Services of Columbus, Ohio, and the Southwestern Investment Company of Amarillo, Tex.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) These were the late trading rates for the dollar in Europe today after the mark revaluation, compared with last Friday: Frankfurt, 1.7690 marks, up from 1.7635; Zurich, 1.5780 Swiss francs, up from 1.5730; Paris, 4.1555 French francs, up from 4.1497; Amsterdam, 1.9485 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9525, and Milan, 807.45 Italian lire, up from 807.35.

Eight prisoners escaped from the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island last night, but three were recaptured within two hours and authorities expressed confidence that the others would soon be rounded up.

SHANGHAI IN the 1950's, peasants in China's Hebeh Province began suffering from a variety of alarming and perplexing symptoms, such as infertility and cardiac irregularities. Prolonged investigation uncovered the cause and has led to what many birth-control specialists consider the most promising male contraceptive pill yet developed.
Governor Carey said yesterday that approval by the voters of the $500 million transportation bond issue in November was not a condition for keeping the 50cent subway fare until 1982.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the proposed multibillion-dollar synthetic fuel program should not be made dependent on revenue from the "windfall" profits tax, as President Carter has proposed.
Governor Carey said he had received a "firm commitment" yesterday from the Carter Administration that New York State would receive next year ...

Marvin Webster came up hurt; Bill Walton played his first game in 17 months and gave himself a passing grade, and Earvin Johnson got good reviews. That was the news Sunday night as three of the National Basketball Association's heralded millionaires began preseason play.
SALEM, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP) A man convicted in a landmark case of raping his estranged wife was sentenced to three to five years today in a maximum-security prison.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24 Officials said today that they were seeking to determine if there was any conspiracy to provoke racial unrest here by outsiders, including four young men who were arrested late Friday for allegedly firing shotgun blasts at the homes of two blacks.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP) --Tom McMillen scored 18 points and Steve Hawes had 16 to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 125-120 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight in National Basketball Association preaseason play.
PARIS, Sept. 25--The street murder of a 35-year-old leftist writer last week has led to warnings here that extremist rightwing and anti-Semitic groups may be starting a campaign of violence.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 25 (AP)--A strike at Shell's giant Pernis refinery and its nearby Moerdijk chemical complex could spread if demands for shorter working hours are not met, union officials said today.

FORT WORTH, Sept. 25 (AP)--State District Judge Gordon Gray announced today that the trial of Cullen Davis, a millionaire oil industrialist, on charges of trying to buy the killing of a judge would resume tomorrow with 11 jurors. The judge said a doctor attending Katheryn Holman, a 53-year-old juror, said she would be hospitalized at least three weeks. Mrs. Holman broke her leg while shopping last weekend, and underwent surgery yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25--Last week the Oakland Police Department made a pair of arrests on marijuana-cultivation charges that have resulted in further re-examination of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s judicial appointments.

The most disastrous single event of the Yankees' year of frustration was a postgame locker-room brawl in which the team's star relief pitcher, Rich Gossage, injured his throwing hand fighting with a big, burly second-string catcher named Cliff Johnson.

TOKYO, Sept. 25--Shortly after the Government announced Japan's next parliamentary election for Oct. 7, about 300 candidates for the 511 seats in the House of Representatives lined up in front of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira at the Tokyo headquarters of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party for a simple but important ceremony.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 25--Two goals in the last eight minutes made up for a sloppy start and allowed the Islanders to win their first National Hockey League exhibition game, 2-1, from the Buffalo Sabres at Nassau Coliseum. The Sabres have yet to win in four contests.

THE simplest and lightest gravies and sauces are those that come from the juices yielded by a roast--any roast--of pork or beef or fowl. They add subtlety to the tenderest meat and they can virtually resurrect a roast that has succumbed to human error.
ATHENS, Sept. 25 (UPI)--A tremor shook the Pella area in northern Greece today, causing two houses to collapse, the police said. There were no reports of injuries.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25--The celebration plans were set in motion after the Cincinnati Reds won at Houston on Sunday, and after the Astros lost a doubleheader yesterday to put the Reds 2 games ahead in the National League Western Division race. The city of Cincinnati planned for its first World Series in three years, and one of its newspapers considered the plans more important than a visit from Vice President Mondale.

Michael Tilson Thomas will conduct opera for the first time in New York in 1981, when he makes his New York City Opera debut in the spring as conductor of Janacek's "Cunning Little Vixen." The announcement was made yesterday by Beverly Sills, general director of the company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--The General Motors Corporation unveiled a new electric power source for a midget car here today, a zinc-nickel oxide battery that corporate executives called a technological breakthrough.

KALANDIA REFUGEE CAMP, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, Sept. 25-- Mixing a preacher's theatrical style with the instinct of a politician on the stump, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson swept through a Palestinian refugee camp outside Jerusalem today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--Propelled once again by energy and housing costs, consumer prices rose by 1.1 percent in August, the seventh consecutive monthly increase of 1 percent or more.

Texas International Airlines announced after a meeting of its board in Houston yesterday that it "intends to continue seeking means" to acquire Trans World Airlines despite the flat refusal by the Trans World Corporation, the parent of T.W.A., to discuss such a combination. Last week the board of Trans World joined the company's management in opposing the Texas International plan.

In their enthusiasms, people who cook without salt are like golfers. Or tennis players. Or skiers. But rather than discuss their latest exploits in sinking a putt or the newest racquets, or the snows of yesteryear and tomorrow, the salt-free people talk about the secrets they use to give special "force" or "emphasis" in flavor to foods.
Jane Fonda, the actress, urged 800 office workers last night to organize and become "a force, as women and as clerical workers."

After days of conflict between Washington and New York State officials over Federal mass-transit aid, Governor Carey and Secretary of Transportation Neil E. Goldschmidt met yesterday evening and agreed that "the combined transit needs of New York City and the state can and will be met."
A Bronx man and his sister were arrested yesterday on charges they had paid $10,000 to a "hit man"--who was in fact an undercover police officer--to murder five men in a revenge conspiracy.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 25 (AP)-- South Africa granted union rights to the nation's black majority today, including the two large worker categories that had been excluded under a similar directive in the spring.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25--The New York Mets, within one strike of losing their fifth doubleheader in eight days, rallied to tie the Chicago Cubs today, then beat them, 4-3, in 10 innings and gained a split. The Cubs, with a seven-run first inning, won the opener, 11-3, giving the Mets their 99th defeat of the season.

New York City's Polish-American community, which had sought to play a major role in the visit of Pope John Paul II to the city, will get at least a small part, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI)-- Yeoman 3d Class Lee Eugene Madsen, a Pentagon security officer, pleaded guilty today to a single count charging that he had sold seven "top secret" intelligence and military documents to an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--The Federal Communications Commission today struck down a rule limiting communities to one over-the-air pay television station each, clearing the way for more rapid expansion of the industry.

Bucky Dent whose fortunes plummeted as quickly this season as they soared after last year's World Series, sat on the bench with his .230 batting average last night and watched Damaso Garcia provide a glimmer of support to the Yankees' hopes that he can replace Dent as their shortstop next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)--An interfaith committee of religious news officials has expressed its concern about a series of Supreme Court rulings that the committee believes curtail freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--A report by the Carter Administration on Moscow's compliance with the 1972 strategic arms accord has concluded that in recent years the Soviet Union has made several apparent attempts to deceive the United States on the size and capabilities of its nuclear arsenal.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 25 (Reuters) --The ruling Islamic clergy reiterated today its demand for a purge of the oil industry's chief executive.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters)--The Reliance Group Inc. said today that it had received acceptances covering some 64 percent of Rothschild Investment Trust Ltd.'s ordinary shares, following its $6.50-a-share bid to acquire 5.4 milllon shares, or 23.9 percent.
Prices of silver futures tumbled yesterday as nervous traders with large paper profits sought other stores of value, such as copper, which scored limit advances on all deliveries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--The National Association of Manufacturers today opposed special Federal financial assistance for the Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--Larry Pressler, a freshman Senator from South Dakota, announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination today, making him the eighth candidate and, at 37, the youngest contender for the office.

SURELY Northern Boulevard in Long Island City is one of the stronger spines of production and distribution in the city. Among the names that grace the major commercial properties are Gallo Wines, Standard Motor Products, Columbia Pictures and Ronzoni Macaroni. The latter is a longtime fixture that recently built a formidable addition to its main manufacturing plant.

WEMBLEY, England, Sept. 25 (AP) --Maurice Hope of Britain stopped Mike Baker of Spartanburg, S.C., at 2 minutes 30 seconds of the seventh round tonight and retained the World Boxing Council's light-middleweight title.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25--There is something awesome in Willie Stargell's home runs as the ball dives into a sea of waving arms and clutching hands, each grasping for a piece of the moment.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25-- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union today dismissed as "artificial" the United States' concern over the Soviet brigade in Cuba and urged Washington to drop the matter.

NEWARK, Sept. 25--A jury of 10 men and six women was selected today for the trial of four resident aliens accused of abducting the wife of a Paterson banker in July and holding her for more than $200,000 in ransom.

AMID the marbled hallways of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, the new Saudi Arabian Ambassador, Faisal Alhegelan, and his wife, Nouha, made their Washington debut Monday night, and they did it with the help of a cast of a thousand.

In winning the world junior championship in Skien, Norway, Yasser Seirawan of Seattle automatically earned international-master rank. He also has a grandmaster norm, achieved at this year's Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif. He needs two more to obtain that rank.

Philip L. Alger, an electrical engineer for nearly 40 years with the General Electric Company, where he took part in the early development of electric motors and electric-motor drives, died Monday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 85 years old, and lived in Schenectady.

An application of suit preference signaling methods that is often overlooked by average players occurs at the second trick. A player who has given a discouraging signal on the first trick may well have a choice of plays next time, and can seize the opportunity to point to some other suit.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25--One of three shotgun blasts fired into the home of Walter Saxon, a black housepainter, from a passing pickup truck last Friday night blew out a secondfloor bedroom window and left seven pellet holes in the ceiling, about two feet above the heads of three adults and two children who were watching television.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25-- Administration officials are consulting with allies and Congress on steps to alleviate expected military and refugee pressures on Thailand caused by the apparent new Vietnam offensive in Cambodia, American officials said today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 25--The "magic number" reached zero here tonight as the California "Yes We Can" Angels clinched their first divisional baseball championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)--The Department of Housing and Urban Development raised to a record 10.5 percent today the maximum interest rate that will be allowed on Government-insured home mortgages.

President Carter used his "town meeting" in Queens last night to criticize his chief potential rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, as an ineffective champion of his own legislative program.

A memorial service for J. Donald Pringle, a former deputy chief of the United Nations Radio Service, will be held at 6:30 P.M. today at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 73d Street and Madison Avenue. Mr. Pringle died last week at the age of 65 at his home in Manhattan. After retiring in 1974 after 28 years on the United Nations staff, he became a United Nations correspondent for Radio Eireann, the Irish radio network.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)--President Carter today signed disaster declarations for six Texas counties and three Louisiana parishes. The areas were struck by severe storms and floods last week.

Treadway Companies Inc. announced yesterday that it had filed a complaint in Federal court in New York against the Care Corporation and two officers. NEWARK, Oct. 3--Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, through his attorney, today released a one-sentence statement in response to reports that a Federal grand jury is investigating campaign fund-raising activities conducted during his 1974 re-election campaign.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 3 (Reuters) --Nearly 11,000 Indochinese refugees left Thailand for new homes abroad last month, a record monthly figure, officials of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today. The figure of 10,854 was nearly 3,000 more than the goal the United Nations group set after the Geneva conference on Indochinese refugees in July. A record 5,890 went to the United States.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)-- Bishop Alden Bell, the Roman Catholic leader of Sacramento, was stabbed twice today by a man wielding a knife. The 75year-old bishop, who had planned to fly to Chicago tomorrow to see Pope John Paul II, was listed in good condition at Mercy General Hospital.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 3 (AP)--Crown Zellerbach Canada Ltd. said today that it would expand newsprint operations at its Elk Falls, British Columbia, mill, following a decision by British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority to deliver more electric power to Vancouver Island.

In a day of credit market records, the Treasury sold two-year notes yesterday at a yield of 10.21 percent, their highest rate of return in modern times. Bell System corporate bond yields climbed to 10.20 percent, also a new high.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP)--A Federal judge has ruled that the Detroit Police Department's affirmative action program is legal and necessary "because it undoes years of discrimination" and "serves vital city needs."

LONDON, Oct. 3--Britain put forward today what it said was its final draft of a constitution for Zimbabwe Rhodesia, and then adjourned until Monday the conference that it is conducting here, with a plea for agreement on the document then.

HOMEOWNERS and apartment dwellers can make their own rigid storm win dows for the inside or outside by using a recently introduced vinyl framing kit that can be assembled with ordinary window glass or clear acrylic plastic.

FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP)-- Andy Johnson, the New England Patriots veteran running back, was declared sidelined for the season today because of a left knee injury suffered in Green Bay Monday night.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP)-- Ronnie Perry, the basketball and baseball star at Holy Cross College here, underwent exploratory knee surgery in Boston today to remedy persistent pain diagnosed as resulting from tendinitis.

BANGUI, Central African Republic --This capital's students and teachers, an elite and potent force of several thousand who rose in protest against former Emperor Bokassa I in January and were quieted only with the aid of Zairian troops, are already unhappy with the new President, David Dacko, as well as with his top advisers, the French.
ATLANTA, Oct. 3 (AP)--The Georgia Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by Marcus Wayne Chenault, who has been sentenced to death for the murder of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s mother.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--Although President Carter has reaffirmed the importance of the Administration's program for creating a quick-reaction military strike force for use in foreign crises, Government officials report that little has been done to organize such a unit.

WASHINGTON (UPI)--Substantial quantities of lunar rock samples brought back from the moon by the Apollo astronauts are missing, according to an internal audit by investigators for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP)--New-car sales by the Big Three automobile companies declined 21 percent in the final 10 days of September from the year-earlier level, while sales for the entire 1979 model year, which ended Sunday, declined 6.8 percent, the companies reported.
The stock market ended mixed yesterday in slower trading as the dollar firmed against several major currencies and the price of gold fell sharply in trading abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--Sixteen owners of 1970-71 Fiat Spyder 850 sports cars told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today that the automobile manufacturer's voluntary recall of the car was a "joke" because of low repurchase prices and that many unsafe vehicles would therefore remain on the roads.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP)--Richard M. Nixon did not take the hint when President Eisenhower tried to ease him off the 1956 Republican ticket, according to a Carnegie-Mellon University professor who has seen the general's private papers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)--The General Motors Corporation was found today to be illegally discriminating against independent body shops that compete against G.M. dealers for jobs repairing crash-damaged cars.

BALBOA, Panama, Oct. 3 (AP)--Vice President Mondale returned to Washington yesterday after taking a cruise on the Panama Canal and flying over the former Canal Zone in a helicopter. Mr. Mondale was in Panama to represent the United States at the ceremonies Monday marking the turnover of the area to Panama by the United States.

Stopping the wave of cross-burnings on the lawns of black families in the New York area is the job of local law enforcement agencies. But there is room also for Federal law enforcement, both to deter such vicious vandalism and to encourage local agencies to act against it. So it is good that a United States Attorney has brought a Federal criminal case against a young cross-burner in Ridgefield, Conn.

In a step to reduce overlapping regulation in the securities industry, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would assume responsibility for surveillance of the commodities accounts of its members.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)--After two months of declines, new orders received by the nation's factories rose 2 percent in August to $142.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 (UPI)--The Chrysler Corporation said today that it completed the sale of the Chrysler Realty Corporation to ABKO Realty Inc. of Wichita, Kan., for $195 million. The subsidiary was formed in 1967 to help develop Chrysler's dealership properties. The accord assures Chrysler of the continued availability of dealership sites owned by Chrysler Realty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--In 1968, William A. Kubrick, a partly disabled Korean War veteran, left a Veterans Administration hospital after treatment for a bone infection in his leg and began to lose his hearing. Within a year he was nearly totally deaf. He sued the Federal Government for malpractice in 1972 and won a $320,000 judgment.

Safeway Stores Inc., the nation's largest supermarket chain, operating primarily west of the Mississippi, reported yesterday that it had profit increases of 30.3 percent in the third quarter ended Sept. 8 and 8.9 percent for the nine-month period.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3--John Cardinal Krol, the sometimes controversial 68-year-old Archbishop of Philadelphia, has acquired in his 18 years of ecclesiastical command here a reputation as a fair-minded defender of traditionalism.

Federal prosecutors presented testimony and tape recordings yesterday in an effort to show that Anthony M. Scotto had purchased a $26,485 sports car in a surreptitious manner to conceal cash from the Internal Revenue Service.

The Reynolds Metals Company yesterday joined other major aluminum producers in raising the price of ingot, the industry's basic product, by 3 cents, to 66 cents a pound. The company also raised prices for other primary ingot products by 4 cents a pound.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP)--A remark by a potential juror, the applause of some fellow panelists and a sharp rebuke from the judge led yesterday to a mistrial in Albany County Court.

RICHMOND, Oct. 3 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission is not carrying out the intent of Congress to revitalize the nation's railroads, an appeals court said today in ordering the agency to reconsider its denial of rate increases for lumber and forest products.

ATLANTA, Oct. 3 (AP)--Walt Bellamy, a former star in the National Basketball Association, was arrested last night and charged with possession of a stolen camera, the Atlanta police reported today.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 3--Nigeria's new civilian President, the first after more than 13 years of military rule, prides himself on being a "contact person," someone who meets scores of ordinary people every day and inquires about their troubles.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 2--Senior Saudi officials here vow to intensify efforts to stabilize the Persian Gulf region and to persuade the United States to take a "more forceful stand" against what they see as Soviet ambitions to encircle the major oil-producing area.

Pope John Paul II and New York City bade each other an emotional farewell at Shea Stadium yesterday, the Pontiff speaking fondly of the special qualities of the city in four of its tongues and thousands of its people replying with applause.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Oct. 3 (UPI) --Bill Cartwright, a rookie center, scored 18 points and grabbed 13 rebounds tonight to carry the New York Knicks to a 87-81 exhibition victory over the Washington Bullets.

IVREA, Italy--Carlo de Benedetti, the 44-year-old chief executive officer and controlling shareholder in Olivetti, the giant Italian office-equipment maker, is giving Giovanni Agnelli, the head of Fiat, a run for his money for the title of Italy's best-known businessman.

BOSTON, Oct. 3--It was awkward surgery on a self-inflicted wound, and performed well enough considering the difficulty. But it remains to be seen whether President Carter's speech can repair the damage done to the strategic arms treaty by his own Administration's foolishness over Soviet troops in Cuba.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission, acting just hours before a Federal deadline for the resumption of service on the strikebound Rock Island railroad, extended that deadline today by two days.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP)--The State Commission on Judicial Conduct has found that six more town and village justices should be censured for ticket fixing.
EXETER, England, Oct. 3 (UPI)-- The Barbarians, the touring multiracial rugby team from South Africa, defeated Devon by 27-18 today in the first of the eight matches that they are to play in Britain.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 3 (AP) --Billie Jean King and Tracy Austin moved into the quarterfinals of the United States women's indoor tennis championships with straight-set victories tonight at the Met Sports Center.
